Analysis and modeling of the Kdp system under conditions of limiting potassium suggests an inverse correlation between KdpDE phosphorylation and the intracellular K+ concentration. Under this model low intracellular K+ levels result in inhibition of the phosphatase activity of KdpD
TorSR system also triggers alkaline stress defence mechanisms to counteract the increasing pH resulting from TMA production
Salmonella typhimurium
Unidentified regulatory function (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1913430/)
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15322361

It may be that the Bae signal transduction apparatus recognizes a distinct type of envelope protein misfolding that is induced by some of the same cues that lead to induction of the Cpx pathway. Alternatively, the Bae pathway may sense some other aspect of cell physiology that is perturbed in response to these treatments. Indole has been proposed to exert its toxicity through oxidative damage as a result of membrane disruptions that expose redox-cycling compounds. Perhaps the Bae two-component system responds to changes in membranes or alternatively to perturbations in redox potential in the envelope
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20946850
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3042748

NtrB is a dual function cytoplasmic protein with both histidine kinase and phosphatase activity - it is regulated negatively by the homologous signal proteins PII (GlnB) and PII2 (GlnK) and the uridyyltransferase/uridylyl-removing enzyme (product of GlnD)
Under stress conditions CpxP is displaced from CpxA and the Cpx response is activated
The specific ligand activating CreC is not currently known

The systems have a discriminatory response to nitrate and nitrite and there is cross talk between the sensor kinases and the response regulators. In this way a complex response to the dynamic ratio of nitrate and nitrite during anaerobiosis is mediated.
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8412692 (Figure 1)
